comment_text.mn27:1.1: This sutta urges against drawing rash conclusions, insisting on a cautious and pragmatic approach to the truth. The theme of epistemological caution is further developed in such suttas as MN 47, MN 60, and MN 99. | According to the Sinhalese chronicle Mahāvaṁsa 14.22, this was the first discourse taught by the arahant Mahinda to King Devanampiyatissa, leading to his conversion and the spread of Buddhism in Sri Lanka. This would have been around 250 BCE.
comment_text.mn27:2.1: A chariot drawn by mares was the preferred vehicle of Jānussoṇi (MN 99:30.1, SN 45.4:1.3), as well as the brahmin student Ambaṭṭha DN 3:1.6.1. Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.2.1 depicts Jānaśruti’s wealth as including cows, gold, and a chariot drawn by mules.
comment_text.mn27:2.2: Pilotika Vacchāyana is not mentioned elsewhere. His first name means “patch” and may be a reference to his patchwork robe (cp. “Ajita of the hair-blanket”). Vacchāyana is a patronymic, possibly indicating he was of the lineage of Vātsya, a student of Yājñavalkya (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 9.5.1.62, Brahmāṇḍa Purāṇa 2.35.29).
comment_text.mn27:2.7: As at MN 99:30.7 and AN 5.194:2.4. The Buddha speaks of his own lucidity of wisdom at MN 12:62.6.
comment_text.mn27:3.1: The text differentiates “bull elephant” (nāga), “elephant” (hatthi), and “cow elephant” (hatthinī). This is essential to the parable, as the tracker is specifically seeking a bull.
comment_text.mn27:3.3: The Pali phrase niṭṭhaṁ gaccheyya is an exact match for the English idiom “come to a conclusion”.
comment_text.mn27:10.6: This passage names three kinds of cow elephants unknown elsewhere. From the context they must be of ascending height. The first is the “dwarf” (vāmanikā).
comment_text.mn27:10.12: Kāḷārikā is related to Sanskrit karāla, which may mean “lofty” or “with gaping teeth”. The commentary applies the latter meaning, but surely the former fits the context.
comment_text.mn27:10.18: One of the many Indic names for elephants, especially cows, is kareṇu (Pali kaṇeru by metathesis), which, being from the root kara (“doer” = “hand”), has the same meaning as the more common hatthi, namely “handy”. I think the kaṇerukā is the “leader of the cows”, i.e. the matriarch.
comment_text.mn27:11.1: This is the start of the teaching on the Gradual Training, encompassing ethics (sīla), meditation (samādhi), and wisdom (paññā).
comment_text.mn27:13.1: The first and most important precept. It is not just the negative injunction to avoid killing, but also the positive injunction to have compassion for all creatures. If a monastic murders a human being they are immediately and permanently expelled.
comment_text.mn27:13.2: To steal anything of substantial value is an expulsion offence.
comment_text.mn27:13.3: “Chastity” is brahmacariya, literally “divine conduct”. Here it is used in the narrow sense of refraining from sex, but more commonly it has a broader sense of “spiritual life”. Buddhist monastics are forbidden from any form of sexual activity. To engage in penetrative intercourse is an expulsion offence.
comment_text.mn27:13.4: This is the first of the four kinds of right speech. Just as the precept of not killing implies the positive injunction to live with compassion, the precepts on speech enjoin a positive and constructive use of speech. If a monastic falsely claims states of enlightenment or deep meditation they are expelled.
comment_text.mn27:13.5: “Harmony” (or “unanimity”, samagga) does not excuse untrue, bigoted, or otherwise harmful speech. True harmony is only achieved in the presence of the Dhamma.
comment_text.mn27:13.7: Attha is a polyvalent term, here taking the senses “meaningful” and “beneficial”. Elsewhere it means “goal”, “need”, “purpose”, “lawsuit”, or “ending”, and the senses are not always easy to untangle.
comment_text.mn27:13.8: Buddhists generally do not regard plants as sentient, but value them as part of the ecosystem that supports all life.
comment_text.mn27:13.9: From MN 66:6.4 and MN 70:4.8 we can see that “at night” means after dark, while “at the wrong time” means in the afternoon. More explicitly, these are the “wrong time at night” and the “wrong time in the day”, in which case they are both the “wrong time”.
comment_text.mn27:13.10: Such sensual entertainments distract and excite the mind. This and the next three precepts encourage peace of mind for meditation.
comment_text.mn27:13.11: This was ignored by the Buddha’s cousin, Nanda (SN 21.8:1.2).
comment_text.mn27:13.13: Literally “gold and silver” (jātarūparajata), but rajata is explained in Bu NP 18:2.8 as currency of any kind.
comment_text.mn27:13.14: Mendicants receive only the day’s meal and do not store or cook food.
comment_text.mn27:13.17: According to ancient Indian law (Arthaśāstra 3.13), a person in a time of trouble may bind themselves in service for a fee. Such bondservants were protected against cruelty, sexual abuse, and unfair work. After earning back the fee of their indenture they were freed, retaining their original inheritance and status.
comment_text.mn27:13.18: These are animals raised for food.
comment_text.mn27:13.21: Land for a monastery may be accepted by the Saṅgha as a community, but not by individual mendicants.
comment_text.mn27:13.22: These items are discussed in detail below. | Acting as a go-between for lay business was tempting due to the mendicants’ wandering lifestyle. However, it exposes them to risk if the message is not delivered or if it is bad news.
comment_text.mn27:13.23: For example, trading in monastery property.
comment_text.mn27:14.1: A Buddhist monk has three robes: a lower robe (sabong or sarong), an upper robe, and an outer cloak. | Here begins the series of practices that build on moral fundamentals to lay the groundwork for meditation. The sequence of contentment, mindfulness, and sense restraint sometimes varies (eg. DN 2:64.1).
comment_text.mn27:14.4: As at DN 2:63.4. This phrase perhaps belongs before contentment.
comment_text.mn27:15.2: It is not that one cannot see things, but that, mindful of its effect, one avoids unnecessary stimulation. | “Covetousness and bitterness” (abhijjhā domanassā) are the strong forms of desire and aversion caused by lack of restraint.
comment_text.mn27:15.9: As at DN 2:64.10, their happiness deepens, as they see that not only their actions but also their mind is becoming free of anything unwholesome.
comment_text.mn27:16.1: Situational awareness is a psychological term popularized in the 1990s. It has to do with the perception of environmental phenomena and the comprehension of their meaning, which is very close to the sense of the Pali term sampajañña. | These acts describe the daily life of a mendicant: going into the village for alms, at which time there are many distracting sights. Then they return, eat their meal, and spend their day in meditation.
comment_text.mn27:17.2: The Jain Ācārāṅgasūtra 1.8.2 notes many places used by Mahāvīra for meditation, including a charnel ground, an empty hut, and the root of a tree.
comment_text.mn27:18.1: For parimukha (“in their presence”) we find pratimukha in Sanskrit, which can mean “presence” or the reflection of the face. Late canonical Pali explains parimukha as “the tip of the nose or the reflection of the face (mukhanimitta)”. Parimukha in Sanskrit is rare, but it appears in Pāṇini 4.4.29, which the commentary illustrates with the example of a servant “in the presence” of their master (cp. SN 47.8). So it seems the sense is “before the face” or more generally “in the presence”. | To “establish mindfulness” (satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā) is literally to “do satipaṭṭhāna”.
comment_text.mn27:18.2: Covetousness (abhijjha) has been curbed by sense restraint, and now is fully abandoned.
comment_text.mn27:18.3: Likewise ill will (byāpādapadosa), which was called domanassa in the formula for sense restraint.
comment_text.mn27:18.4: “Mindfulness and situational awareness” has a prominent role in abandoning dullness.
comment_text.mn27:18.5: Restlessness hankers for the future and is countered by contentment. Remorse digs up the past and is countered by ethical purity.
comment_text.mn27:18.6: The meditator set out on their path after gaining faith in the Buddha.
comment_text.mn27:19.1: The five hindrances remain a pillar of meditation teaching. The root sense means to “obstruct” but also to “obscure, darken, veil”.
comment_text.mn27:19.3: The first true footprint of the Buddha is jhāna, not skill in debate or conversion, nor even ethical conduct. Compare DN 2:76.3, where jhāna was the first superior fruit of the spiritual life.
comment_text.mn27:19.4: Just as the bull elephant tracker does not come to a conclusion until they have found a bull elephant, here the meditator has not confirmed that the Buddha’s teaching leads to the goal that was promised.
comment_text.mn27:25.5: They are in the culminating stages of the path.
comment_text.mn27:26.5: Faith, reason, evidence, and experience have all played a role in the discovery of truth. But there can be no certainty until the truth has accomplished its ultimate function, freedom from suffering.

root_text.mn27:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn27:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāti divādivassa.
root_text.mn27:2.2: Addasā kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo pilotikaṁ paribbājakaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn27:2.4: “Handa kuto nu bhavaṁ vacchāyano āgacchati divādivassā”ti?
root_text.mn27:2.5: “Ito hi kho ahaṁ, bho, āgacchāmi samaṇassa gotamassa santikā”ti.
root_text.mn27:2.6: “Taṁ kiṁ maññati bhavaṁ vacchāyano samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṁ paṇḍito maññe”ti.
root_text.mn27:2.7: “Ko cāhaṁ, bho, ko ca samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṁ jānissāmi.
root_text.mn27:2.8: Sopi nūnassa tādisova yo samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṁ jāneyyā”ti.
root_text.mn27:2.9: “Uḷārāya khalu bhavaṁ vacchāyano samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ pasaṁsāya pasaṁsatī”ti.
root_text.mn27:2.10: “Ko cāhaṁ, bho, ko ca samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ pasaṁsissāmi,
root_text.mn27:2.11: pasatthapasatthova so bhavaṁ gotamo seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.
root_text.mn27:2.12: “Kaṁ pana bhavaṁ vacchāyano atthavasaṁ sampassamāno samaṇe gotame evaṁ abhippasanno”ti?
root_text.mn27:3.2: So passeyya nāgavane mahantaṁ hatthipadaṁ, dīghato ca āyataṁ, tiriyañca vitthataṁ.
root_text.mn27:3.5: Evameva kho ahaṁ, bho, yato addasaṁ samaṇe gotame cattāri padāni athāhaṁ niṭṭhamagamaṁ:
root_text.mn27:3.6: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:4.2: Idhāhaṁ, bho, passāmi ekacce khattiyapaṇḍite nipuṇe kataparappavāde vālavedhirūpe, te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
root_text.mn27:4.4: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṁ nāma gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā osarissatī’ti.
root_text.mn27:4.6: ‘imaṁ mayaṁ pañhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma.
root_text.mn27:4.7: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṁ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṁ vādaṁ āropessāma.
root_text.mn27:4.8: Evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṁ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṁ vādaṁ āropessāmā’ti.
root_text.mn27:4.10: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṁ nāma gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā osaṭo’ti.
root_text.mn27:4.12: Te samaṇo gotamo dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṁseti.
root_text.mn27:4.13: Te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṁsitā na ceva samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ pañhaṁ pucchanti, kutossa vādaṁ āropessanti?

root_text.mn27:7.5: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṁ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṁ vādaṁ āropessāma.
root_text.mn27:7.6: Evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṁ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṁ vādaṁ āropessāmā’ti.
root_text.mn27:7.7: Te suṇanti ‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo amukaṁ nāma gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā osaṭo’ti.
root_text.mn27:7.9: Te samaṇo gotamo dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṁseti.
root_text.mn27:7.10: Te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṁsitā na ceva samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ pañhaṁ pucchanti, kutossa vādaṁ āropessanti?
root_text.mn27:7.11: Aññadatthu samaṇaṁyeva gotamaṁ okāsaṁ yācanti agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajjāya.
root_text.mn27:7.13: Te tattha pabbajitā samānā vūpakaṭṭhā appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
root_text.mn27:7.15: ‘manaṁ vata, bho, anassāma, manaṁ vata, bho, panassāma;
root_text.mn27:7.16: mayañhi pubbe assamaṇāva samānā samaṇamhāti paṭijānimha, abrāhmaṇāva samānā brāhmaṇamhāti paṭijānimha, anarahantova samānā arahantamhāti paṭijānimha.

root_text.mn27:8.1: Evaṁ vutte, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo sabbasetā vaḷavābhirathā orohitvā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
root_text.mn27:8.5: Appeva nāma mayampi kadāci karahaci tena bhotā gotamena saddhiṁ samāgaccheyyāma, appeva nāma siyā kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.
root_text.mn27:9.1: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn27:9.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn27:9.3: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yāvatako ahosi pilotikena paribbājakena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
root_text.mn27:9.4: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā jāṇussoṇiṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn27:9.5: “na kho, brāhmaṇa, ettāvatā hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hoti.
root_text.mn27:9.6: Api ca, brāhmaṇa, yathā hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hoti
root_text.mn27:9.7: taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn27:9.8: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.mn27:10.2: So passeyya nāgavane mahantaṁ hatthipadaṁ, dīghato ca āyataṁ, tiriyañca vitthataṁ.
root_text.mn27:10.3: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:10.6: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane vāmanikā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṁ petaṁ padaṁ assāti.
root_text.mn27:10.8: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṁ hatthipadaṁ, dīghato ca āyataṁ, tiriyañca vitthataṁ, uccā ca nisevitaṁ.
root_text.mn27:10.9: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:10.12: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane uccā kāḷārikā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṁ petaṁ padaṁ assāti.
root_text.mn27:10.14: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṁ hatthipadaṁ, dīghato ca āyataṁ, tiriyañca vitthataṁ, uccā ca nisevitaṁ, uccā ca dantehi ārañjitāni.
root_text.mn27:10.15: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:10.18: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane uccā kaṇerukā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṁ petaṁ padaṁ assāti.
root_text.mn27:10.20: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṁ hatthipadaṁ, dīghato ca āyataṁ, tiriyañca vitthataṁ, uccā ca nisevitaṁ, uccā ca dantehi ārañjitāni, uccā ca sākhābhaṅgaṁ.
root_text.mn27:10.21: Tañca nāgaṁ passati rukkhamūlagataṁ vā abbhokāsagataṁ vā gacchantaṁ vā tiṭṭhantaṁ vā nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā.
root_text.mn27:11.1: Evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn27:11.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn27:11.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ; kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn27:12.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn27:12.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn27:12.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn27:12.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn27:12.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn27:12.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn27:13.1: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn27:13.2: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn27:13.3: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
root_text.mn27:13.4: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
root_text.mn27:13.5: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn27:13.6: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn27:13.7: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn27:14.1: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn27:14.2: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
root_text.mn27:14.3: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn27:14.4: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn27:15.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn27:15.2: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn27:15.7: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn27:15.8: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn27:15.9: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn27:16.1: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn27:17.1: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
root_text.mn27:17.2: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn27:18.1: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn27:18.2: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn27:18.3: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn27:18.4: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn27:18.5: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati, ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn27:18.6: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn27:19.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
root_text.mn27:19.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn27:19.3: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:19.4: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:19.5: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:20.1: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn27:21.1: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn27:22.1: Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn27:22.2: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:22.3: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:22.4: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:23.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn27:23.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn27:23.3: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:23.4: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:23.5: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:24.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn27:24.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn27:24.3: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:24.4: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:24.5: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:25.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn27:25.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn27:25.3: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn27:25.4: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:25.5: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gato hoti, api ca kho niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn27:25.6: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:26.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn27:26.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn27:26.4: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṁ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṁ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṁ itipi.
root_text.mn27:26.5: Ettāvatā kho, brāhmaṇa, ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṁ gato hoti:
root_text.mn27:26.6: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
root_text.mn27:26.7: Ettāvatā kho, brāhmaṇa, hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hotī”ti.
root_text.mn27:27.1: Evaṁ vutte, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn27:27.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn27:27.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn27:27.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.mn27:0.2: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint
translation_text.mn27:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn27:2.1: Now at that time the brahmin Jānussoṇi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.
translation_text.mn27:2.2: He saw the wanderer Pilotika coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn27:2.4: “So, worthy Vacchāyana, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
translation_text.mn27:2.5: “Just now, good fellow, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”
translation_text.mn27:2.6: “What do you think of the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom? Do you think he’s astute?”
translation_text.mn27:2.7: “My good man, who am I to judge the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom?
translation_text.mn27:2.8: You’d really have to be on the same level to judge his lucidity of wisdom.”
translation_text.mn27:2.9: “Mister Vacchāyana praises the ascetic Gotama with high praise indeed.”
translation_text.mn27:2.10: “Who am I to praise the ascetic Gotama?
translation_text.mn27:2.11: He is praised by the praised as the first among gods and humans.”
translation_text.mn27:2.12: “But for what reason are you so devoted to the ascetic Gotama?”
translation_text.mn27:3.1: “Suppose that a skilled bull elephant tracker were to enter a bull elephant wood.
translation_text.mn27:3.2: There he’d see a large elephant’s footprint, long and broad.
translation_text.mn27:3.3: He would come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:3.4: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’
translation_text.mn27:3.5: In the same way, because I saw four footprints of the ascetic Gotama I came to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:3.6: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:4.2: Firstly, I see some clever aristocrats who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.
translation_text.mn27:4.4: ‘So, gentlemen, that ascetic Gotama will come down to such and such village or town.’
translation_text.mn27:4.6: ‘We’ll approach the ascetic Gotama and ask him this question.
translation_text.mn27:4.7: If he answers like this, we’ll refute him like that;
translation_text.mn27:4.8: and if he answers like that, we’ll refute him like this.’
translation_text.mn27:4.12: The ascetic Gotama educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires them with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.mn27:4.13: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the ascetic Gotama, so how could they refute his answer?
translation_text.mn27:4.15: When I saw this first footprint of the ascetic Gotama, I came to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:4.16: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:5.1: Furthermore, I see some clever brahmins …
translation_text.mn27:7.1: Furthermore, I see some clever ascetics who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. …
translation_text.mn27:7.10: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the ascetic Gotama, so how could they refute his answer?
translation_text.mn27:7.11: Invariably, they ask the ascetic Gotama for the chance to go forth.
translation_text.mn27:7.12: And he gives them the going-forth.
translation_text.mn27:7.13: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, they realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn27:7.15: ‘We were almost lost! We almost perished!
translation_text.mn27:7.16: For we used to claim that we were ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones, but we were none of these things.
translation_text.mn27:7.17: But now we really are ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones!’
translation_text.mn27:7.18: When I saw this fourth footprint of the ascetic Gotama, I came to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:7.19: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:7.20: It’s because I saw these four footprints of the ascetic Gotama that I came to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:7.21: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’”
translation_text.mn27:8.1: When he had spoken, Jānussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
translation_text.mn27:8.2: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn27:8.3: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn27:8.4: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn27:8.5: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet the worthy Gotama, and we can have a discussion.”
translation_text.mn27:9.1: Then the brahmin Jānussoṇi went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn27:9.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn27:9.3: and informed the Buddha of all he had discussed with the wanderer Pilotika.
translation_text.mn27:9.4: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn27:9.5: “Brahmin, the simile of the elephant’s footprint is not yet completed in detail.
translation_text.mn27:9.6: As to how it is completed in detail,
translation_text.mn27:9.7: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn27:10.1: “Suppose a bull elephant tracker were to enter a bull elephant wood.
translation_text.mn27:10.2: There they’d see a large elephant’s footprint, long and broad.
translation_text.mn27:10.3: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:10.4: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’
translation_text.mn27:10.6: Because in an elephant wood there are dwarf cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
translation_text.mn27:10.8: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces high up.
translation_text.mn27:10.9: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:10.10: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’
translation_text.mn27:10.12: Because in an elephant wood there are tall lofty cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
translation_text.mn27:10.14: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces and tusk-marks high up.
translation_text.mn27:10.15: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:10.16: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’
translation_text.mn27:10.18: Because in an elephant wood there are tall matriarch cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
translation_text.mn27:10.20: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces, tusk-marks, and broken branches high up.
translation_text.mn27:10.21: And they see that bull elephant walking, standing, sitting, or lying down at the root of a tree or in the open.
translation_text.mn27:10.22: Then they’d come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:11.1: In the same way, brahmin, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn27:11.2: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn27:11.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely complete and pure.
translation_text.mn27:12.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn27:12.2: They gain faith in the Realized One,
translation_text.mn27:12.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn27:12.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn27:12.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn27:12.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn27:13.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn27:13.2: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.mn27:13.3: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.mn27:13.4: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.mn27:13.5: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn27:13.6: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn27:13.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn27:13.8: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.mn27:13.9: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and at the wrong time.
translation_text.mn27:13.10: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music.
translation_text.mn27:13.11: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.mn27:13.12: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.mn27:13.13: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.mn27:13.22: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.mn27:13.26: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.mn27:14.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn27:14.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.mn27:14.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn27:14.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.mn27:15.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn27:15.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn27:15.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn27:15.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn27:15.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn27:15.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn27:15.7: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn27:15.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn27:15.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.mn27:16.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn27:17.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
translation_text.mn27:17.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn27:18.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn27:18.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn27:18.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.mn27:18.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn27:18.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn27:18.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn27:19.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn27:19.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn27:19.3: This, brahmin, is that which is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
translation_text.mn27:19.4: But a noble disciple does not yet come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:19.5: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:20.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn27:20.2: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
translation_text.mn27:21.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn27:21.2: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
translation_text.mn27:22.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn27:22.2: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
translation_text.mn27:23.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn27:23.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn27:23.3: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
translation_text.mn27:24.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn27:24.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn27:24.3: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
translation_text.mn27:25.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn27:25.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn27:25.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
translation_text.mn27:25.4: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
translation_text.mn27:25.5: At this point a noble disciple has not yet come to a conclusion, but they are coming to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:25.6: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:26.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn27:26.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn27:26.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn27:26.4: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
translation_text.mn27:26.5: At this point a noble disciple has come to the conclusion,
translation_text.mn27:26.6: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.mn27:26.7: And it is at this point that the simile of the elephant’s footprint has been completed in detail.”
translation_text.mn27:27.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Jānussoṇi said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn27:27.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn27:27.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn27:27.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

variant_text.mn27:13.8: hoti → imassa anantaraṁ so iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti vacana d ta idha santosakath ca tattha satisampaja
variant_text.mn27:17.1: imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato → etthantare pāṭho idha na dissati, catukkaṅguttare pana imasmiṁ ṭhāne dissati, aṭṭhakathāṭīkāsu ca tadattho pakāsito. tasmā so ettha paṭipūrito. 9M:1388; 10M:1289
